big_picture_notes: Malachi closes the prophetic corpus with a disputation cycle: Yahweh asserts, the people object ('How…? Where…?'), and Yahweh provides proof with judgment or promise. Six (often reckoned seven) disputations create a dialogical, confrontational tone, reinforced by a chiastic arrangement (opening love/offerings ↔ closing remnant/Day of Yahweh) pivoting on covenant fidelity and justice. Literary glue: repeated epithet 'Yahweh of hosts,' pervasive rhetorical questions, and the assertion–objection–response structure that exposes spiritual blindness and summons covenant loyalty.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Superscription and first disputation establish Yahweh’s electing love, answered through Jacob/Esau contrast and Edom’s judgment. Start (1:1): oracle title. End (1:5): recognition 'Great is Yahweh beyond Israel's border.' Glue: disputation pattern (assertion→'How have you loved us?'→proof) and Jacob/Esau antithesis.

scenes.scene_name: Oracle Superscription and YHWH's Love Assertion
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Title opens; love asserted meets 'How have you loved us?'; proof via Jacob loved/Esau hated and Edom’s desolation; closes with doxological recognition. Devices: disputation form, contrastive parallelism, election/judgment rhetoric.

stories.story_title: The Priests' Failure and Defiled Worship
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Second and third disputations target the priesthood: polluted offerings and breach of Levi’s covenant. Start (1:6): honor/fear owed to Father/Master confronts priests. End (2:9): priests made despised for partiality. Glue: repeated 'O priests,' 'despise/contempt,' and offering language across assertion–objection–proof cycles.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'How have we despised your name?' answered by blemished/stolen/sick offerings; irony: 'Present to your governor'; closes with universal fear of Yahweh’s name. Devices: rhetorical questions, irony, contrastive universalism (1:11).

scenes.scene_name: The Covenant of Levi and the Corrupt Priesthood
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Command to priests; threat of rebuke/offspring curse and dung‑shame; ideal Levi covenant (life/peace, true instruction) contrasted with present partiality; ends with despised status. Devices: covenant contrast, shocking metaphor, lex talionis.

stories.story_title: Treachery, Divorce, and the Quest for Justice
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Focus shifts to communal treachery (marriage/divorce) and the people’s challenge about justice, answered by the coming Messenger who purifies and judges. Start (2:10): one Father/one God indictment of faithlessness. End (3:5): swift witness against social/ethical sins. Glue: refrain 'faithless/treacherous' and disputation on justice ('Where is the God of justice?').

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Betrayal via intermarriage and divorce condemned; Yahweh as witness to the 'wife of your youth'; closes with violence/treachery prohibition. Devices: covenant‑marriage metaphor, legal witness, intensified prohibition.

scenes.scene_name: Demand for Justice and the Messenger's Purification
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'How have we wearied?'—by saying evildoers are good/Where is justice? Answer: 'Behold, I send my messenger'; refiner’s fire cleanses Levites, then swift judgment enumerated. Devices: disputation, messenger motif, refiner/launderer similes.

stories.story_title: The Call to Return and the Final Exhortation
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Final disputations and epilogue: unchanging Yahweh calls to return via tithes, distinguishes remnant from cynics, and promises Day of Yahweh with Elijah’s mission. Start (3:6): immutability grounds appeal. End (4:6): hearts turned lest curse—canonical close. Glue: hortatory imperatives ('Return… Bring the full tithe… Remember…'), righteous/wicked contrast, and Day imagery.

scenes.scene_name: Disputation on Robbing God of Tithes
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'How shall we return?' → charge of robbing God; test Yahweh by bringing full tithe; windows of heaven, rebuked devourer, nations call you blessed. Devices: disputation, hortatory 'test,' blessing/curse reversal.

scenes.scene_name: Cynicism of the Wicked and the Remnant's Distinction
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'How have we spoken?'—'It is vain to serve'; remnant fears Yahweh, book of remembrance written; distinction reaffirmed. Devices: contrastive parallelism, memorial book metaphor, remnant motif.

scenes.scene_name: The Day of the LORD and the Promise of Elijah
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Oven‑burning day for arrogant; sun of righteousness for fearers; 'Remember Moses' and 'Behold, I will send Elijah' to turn hearts; canonical warning close. Devices: apocalyptic similes, hortatory inclusio, prophetic forerunner promise.
